config.text: When would you use an emergency area on a motorway?

choices.label: In cases of emergency or breakdown
If you think you'll be involved in a road rage incident
To stop and check where you are
To make a private phone call

correct.text: On some motorways, emergency areas are built at the side of the carriageway. If you break down, try to get your vehicle into the emergency area where there's an emergency telephone. The phone connects directly to a control centre. Before rejoining the motorway, you must call the control centre - a lane may need to be closed to allow you to rejoin safely.

incorrect.text: On some motorways, emergency areas are built at the side of the carriageway. If you break down, try to get your vehicle into the emergency area where there's an emergency telephone. The phone connects directly to a control centre. Before rejoining the motorway, you must call the control centre - a lane may need to be closed to allow you to rejoin safely.

config.text: What should you do if you're driving on a motorway and you miss the exit that you wanted to take?

choices.label: Carefully reverse along the hard shoulder
Carry on to the next exit
Carefully reverse in the left-hand lane
Make a U-turn at the next gap in the central reservation

correct.text: It's illegal to reverse, cross the central reservation or drive against the traffic flow on a motorway. If you miss your exit, carry on until you reach the next one. Ask yourself why you missed your exit – if you think that your concentration is fading, take a break before continuing your journey.

incorrect.text: It's illegal to reverse, cross the central reservation or drive against the traffic flow on a motorway. If you miss your exit, carry on until you reach the next one. Ask yourself why you missed your exit – if you think that your concentration is fading, take a break before continuing your journey.

config.text: Which vehicles should use the left-hand lane on a three-lane motorway?

choices.label: Any vehicle that isn't overtaking
Large vehicles only
Emergency vehicles only
Slow vehicles only

correct.text: On a motorway, all traffic should use the left-hand lane unless overtaking. When overtaking a number of slower vehicles, move back to the left-hand lane when you’re safely past. Check your mirrors frequently and don’t stay in the middle or right-hand lane if the left-hand lane is free.

incorrect.text: On a motorway, all traffic should use the left-hand lane unless overtaking. When overtaking a number of slower vehicles, move back to the left-hand lane when you’re safely past. Check your mirrors frequently and don’t stay in the middle or right-hand lane if the left-hand lane is free.

config.text: What's the national speed limit on motorways for cars and motorcycles?

choices.label: 30 mph
50 mph
60 mph
70 mph

correct.text: Travelling at the national speed limit doesn't allow you to hog the right-hand lane. Always use the left-hand lane whenever possible. When leaving a motorway, get into the left-hand lane well before your exit. Reduce your speed on the slip road and look out for sharp bends or curves and traffic queuing at roundabouts.

incorrect.text: Travelling at the national speed limit doesn't allow you to hog the right-hand lane. Always use the left-hand lane whenever possible. When leaving a motorway, get into the left-hand lane well before your exit. Reduce your speed on the slip road and look out for sharp bends or curves and traffic queuing at roundabouts.

config.text: How do motorways reduce traffic bunching?

choices.label: By using higher speed limits
By using advisory speed limits
By using minimum speed limits
By using variable speed limits

correct.text: You must follow the mandatory signs on the gantries above motorway lanes, including the hard shoulder. Variable speed limits help keep the traffic moving and also help to prevent bunching.

incorrect.text: You must follow the mandatory signs on the gantries above motorway lanes, including the hard shoulder. Variable speed limits help keep the traffic moving and also help to prevent bunching.

config.text: How should you use the lanes on a motorway?

choices.label: Use the lane that has the least traffic
Keep to the left-hand lane unless you're overtaking
Overtake using the lane that’s clearest
Stay in one lane until you reach your exit

correct.text: You should normally travel in the left-hand lane unless you're overtaking a slower-moving vehicle. When you've finished overtaking, move back into the left-hand lane, but don’t cut across in front of the vehicle that you’ve overtaken.

incorrect.text: You should normally travel in the left-hand lane unless you're overtaking a slower-moving vehicle. When you've finished overtaking, move back into the left-hand lane, but don’t cut across in front of the vehicle that you’ve overtaken.

config.text: Why is it particularly important to check your vehicle before making a long motorway journey?

choices.label: You'll have to do more harsh braking on motorways
Motorway services areas don't deal with breakdowns
The road surface will wear down the tyres faster
Continuous high speeds increase the risk of your vehicle breaking down

correct.text: Before you start your journey, make sure that your vehicle can cope with the demands of high-speed driving. You should check a number of things; the main ones being fuel, oil, water and tyres. You also need to plan rest stops if you’re making a long journey.

incorrect.text: Before you start your journey, make sure that your vehicle can cope with the demands of high-speed driving. You should check a number of things; the main ones being fuel, oil, water and tyres. You also need to plan rest stops if you’re making a long journey.

meta.xref: DES s11, HC r269, HC r271

config.text: You're on a motorway. The hard shoulder is not being used as a running lane. When should you use the hard shoulder?

choices.label: When you're stopping in an emergency
When you're leaving the motorway
When you're stopping for a rest
When you're joining the motorway

correct.text: Don't use the hard shoulder for stopping unless it's an emergency. If you want to stop for any other reason, go to the next exit or service area.

incorrect.text: Don't use the hard shoulder for stopping unless it's an emergency. If you want to stop for any other reason, go to the next exit or service area.

config.text: What should you do while you're driving or riding along a motorway?

choices.label: Look much further ahead than you would on other roads
Travel much faster than you would on other roads
Maintain a shorter separation distance than you would on other roads
Concentrate more than you would on other roads

correct.text: Traffic on motorways usually travels faster than on other roads. You need to be looking further ahead to give yourself more time to react to any hazard that may develop.

incorrect.text: Traffic on motorways usually travels faster than on other roads. You need to be looking further ahead to give yourself more time to react to any hazard that may develop.

meta.xref: DES s11, HC r108, HC p125

config.text: Traffic officers operate on motorways and some primary routes in England and Wales. What are they authorised to do?

choices.label: Stop and arrest drivers who break the law
Repair broken-down vehicles on the motorway
Issue fixed penalty notices
Stop and direct anyone on a motorway

correct.text: Traffic officers don't have enforcement powers but are able to stop and direct people on motorways and some 'A' class roads. They operate in England and Wales and work in partnership with the police at incidents, providing a highly trained and visible service. They're recognised by an orange-and-yellow jacket and their vehicle has yellow-and-black markings.

incorrect.text: Traffic officers don't have enforcement powers but are able to stop and direct people on motorways and some 'A' class roads. They operate in England and Wales and work in partnership with the police at incidents, providing a highly trained and visible service. They're recognised by an orange-and-yellow jacket and their vehicle has yellow-and-black markings.

config.text: Which vehicles aren't allowed to use the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway?

choices.label: Small delivery vans
Motorcycles
Vehicles towing a trailer
Motorcycle and sidecar outfits

correct.text: On the motorway, any vehicle towing a trailer is restricted to 60 mph. It isn't allowed in the right-hand lane, as it might hold up faster-moving traffic that wishes to overtake in that lane.

incorrect.text: On the motorway, any vehicle towing a trailer is restricted to 60 mph. It isn't allowed in the right-hand lane, as it might hold up faster-moving traffic that wishes to overtake in that lane.

config.text: You're travelling along a motorway. When are you allowed to overtake on the left?

choices.label: When you can see well ahead that the hard shoulder is clear
When the traffic in the right-hand lane is signalling right
When you warn drivers behind by signalling left
When in queues and traffic to your right is moving more slowly than you are

correct.text: Never overtake on the left, unless the traffic is moving in queues and the queue on your right is moving more slowly than the one you're in.

incorrect.text: Never overtake on the left, unless the traffic is moving in queues and the queue on your right is moving more slowly than the one you're in.

config.text: You're travelling in the left-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. How should you react to traffic joining from a slip road?

choices.label: Increase your speed to ensure they join behind you
Adjust your speed or change lane if you can do so safely
Maintain a steady speed
Switch on your hazard warning lights

correct.text: Plan well ahead when approaching a slip road. If you see traffic joining the motorway, be prepared to adjust your speed or move to another lane if it's safe to do so. This can help the flow of traffic joining the motorway, especially at peak times.

incorrect.text: Plan well ahead when approaching a slip road. If you see traffic joining the motorway, be prepared to adjust your speed or move to another lane if it's safe to do so. This can help the flow of traffic joining the motorway, especially at peak times.

config.text: What's the speed limit for a car towing a trailer on a motorway?

choices.label: 40 mph
50 mph
60 mph
70 mph

correct.text: If you're towing a small, light trailer, it won't reduce your vehicle's performance by very much and it may not be visible in your mirrors. However, strong winds or buffeting from large vehicles might cause the trailer to snake from side to side. Be aware of your speed and don't exceed the reduced speed limit imposed on vehicles towing trailers.

incorrect.text: If you're towing a small, light trailer, it won't reduce your vehicle's performance by very much and it may not be visible in your mirrors. However, strong winds or buffeting from large vehicles might cause the trailer to snake from side to side. Be aware of your speed and don't exceed the reduced speed limit imposed on vehicles towing trailers.

config.text: You're on a motorway. What does it mean when a mandatory speed limit is displayed above the hard shoulder?

choices.label: You shouldn't travel in this lane
The hard shoulder can be used as a running lane
You can park on the hard shoulder if you feel tired
You can pull up in this lane to answer a mobile phone

correct.text: A mandatory speed-limit sign above the hard shoulder shows that this part of the road can be used as a running lane between junctions. You must stay within the speed limit. Look out for vehicles that may have broken down and could be blocking the hard shoulder.

incorrect.text: A mandatory speed-limit sign above the hard shoulder shows that this part of the road can be used as a running lane between junctions. You must stay within the speed limit. Look out for vehicles that may have broken down and could be blocking the hard shoulder.

config.text: What would you expect to find at a contraflow system on a motorway?

choices.label: Temporary traffic lights
Lower speed limits
Wider lanes than normal
Road humps

correct.text: When approaching a contraflow system, reduce speed in good time and obey all speed limits. You may be travelling in a narrower lane than normal, with no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic. Be aware that the hard shoulder may be used for traffic and the road ahead could be obstructed by slow-moving or broken-down vehicles.

incorrect.text: When approaching a contraflow system, reduce speed in good time and obey all speed limits. You may be travelling in a narrower lane than normal, with no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic. Be aware that the hard shoulder may be used for traffic and the road ahead could be obstructed by slow-moving or broken-down vehicles.

config.text: How should you rejoin the motorway after a breakdown on the hard shoulder?

choices.label: Build up speed on the hard shoulder before looking for a safe gap in the traffic
Move straight out into the left-hand lane as you are not allowed to drive on the hard shoulder
Wait until a vehicle in the left-hand lane signals to you that it's safe to rejoin
Keep your hazard lights flashing until you have safely rejoined the carriageway

correct.text: To rejoin a motorway from the hard shoulder, you first need to build up speed on the hard shoulder. You can then look for a safe gap in the traffic in the left-hand lane. Watch for traffic that may be returning from a lane on the right into the left-hand lane.

incorrect.text: To rejoin a motorway from the hard shoulder, you first need to build up speed on the hard shoulder. You can then look for a safe gap in the traffic in the left-hand lane. Watch for traffic that may be returning from a lane on the right into the left-hand lane.

config.text: What should you do when you're approaching roadworks on a motorway?

choices.label: Speed up to clear the area quickly
Always use the hard shoulder
Obey the speed limit
Stay very close to the vehicle in front

correct.text: Be aware of reduced speed limits at roadworks. Speed limits shown inside a red circle are mandatory and cameras are often used to enforce the reduced limit. Slow down in good time and keep your distance from the vehicle in front.

incorrect.text: Be aware of reduced speed limits at roadworks. Speed limits shown inside a red circle are mandatory and cameras are often used to enforce the reduced limit. Slow down in good time and keep your distance from the vehicle in front.

config.text: What should you do immediately after joining a motorway?

choices.label: Try to overtake
Re-adjust your mirrors
Position your vehicle in the centre lane
Stay in the left-hand lane

correct.text: When you've just joined a motorway, stay in the left-hand lane long enough to get used to the higher speeds of motorway traffic before considering overtaking.

incorrect.text: When you've just joined a motorway, stay in the left-hand lane long enough to get used to the higher speeds of motorway traffic before considering overtaking.

config.text: You're on a motorway. What does it mean if a red cross is showing above the hard shoulder and mandatory speed limits above all other lanes?

choices.label: The hard shoulder can be used as a rest area if you feel tired
The hard shoulder is for emergency or breakdown use only
The hard shoulder can be used as a normal running lane
The hard shoulder has a speed limit of 50 mph

correct.text: A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it's closed as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies or breakdowns. On some motorways, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane at busy times. This will be shown by a mandatory speed limit on the gantry above the hard shoulder.

incorrect.text: A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it's closed as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies or breakdowns. On some motorways, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane at busy times. This will be shown by a mandatory speed limit on the gantry above the hard shoulder.

config.text: You have stopped in an emergency area. What must you do before you rejoin the carriageway?

choices.label: Use the emergency telephone
Give an arm signal as you are moving off
Switch on your vehicle's headlights
Move away with your hazard lights on

correct.text: To rejoin the carriageway from an emergency area, you must use the emergency telephone and follow the operator's advice. A lane may have to be closed so that you can rejoin the carriageway safely.

incorrect.text: To rejoin the carriageway from an emergency area, you must use the emergency telephone and follow the operator's advice. A lane may have to be closed so that you can rejoin the carriageway safely.

config.text: Which vehicles are prohibited from using the motorway?

choices.label: Powered mobility scooters
Motorcycles over 50 cc
Double-deck buses
Cars with automatic transmission

correct.text: Motorways mustn’t be used by pedestrians, cyclists, motorcycles under 50 cc, certain slow-moving vehicles without permission, and powered wheelchairs/mobility scooters.

incorrect.text: Motorways mustn’t be used by pedestrians, cyclists, motorcycles under 50 cc, certain slow-moving vehicles without permission, and powered wheelchairs/mobility scooters.

config.text: Your vehicle broke down on the hard shoulder of a motorway, but has now been repaired. How should you rejoin the main carriageway?

choices.label: Move out onto the carriageway, then build up your speed
Move out onto the carriageway using your hazard warning lights
Gain speed on the hard shoulder before moving out onto the carriageway
Wait on the hard shoulder until someone flashes their headlights at you

correct.text: Signal your intention and build up sufficient speed on the hard shoulder so that you can filter into a safe gap in the traffic. Don't push your way into a small gap or cause other traffic to alter speed or direction.

incorrect.text: Signal your intention and build up sufficient speed on the hard shoulder so that you can filter into a safe gap in the traffic. Don't push your way into a small gap or cause other traffic to alter speed or direction.

config.text: What colour are the reflective studs between the lanes on a motorway?

choices.label: Green
Amber
White
Red

correct.text: White studs are found between the lanes on motorways. They reflect back the light from your headlights. This is especially useful in bad weather, when visibility is restricted.

incorrect.text: White studs are found between the lanes on motorways. They reflect back the light from your headlights. This is especially useful in bad weather, when visibility is restricted.

config.text: What does this motorway sign mean?

choices.label: Use any lane except the hard shoulder
Use the hard shoulder only
Use the three right-hand lanes only
Use all the lanes, including the hard shoulder

correct.text: You must obey mandatory speed-limit signs above motorway lanes, including the hard shoulder. In this case, you can use the hard shoulder as a running lane but you should look for any vehicles that may have broken down and may be blocking the hard shoulder.

incorrect.text: You must obey mandatory speed-limit signs above motorway lanes, including the hard shoulder. In this case, you can use the hard shoulder as a running lane but you should look for any vehicles that may have broken down and may be blocking the hard shoulder.

config.text: Your vehicle has broken down on a motorway. In which direction should you walk to find the nearest emergency telephone?

choices.label: With the traffic flow
Facing oncoming traffic
In the direction shown on the marker posts
In the direction of the nearest exit

correct.text: Along the hard shoulder there are marker posts at 100-metre intervals. These will direct you to the nearest emergency telephone.

incorrect.text: Along the hard shoulder there are marker posts at 100-metre intervals. These will direct you to the nearest emergency telephone.

config.text: You stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway and use the emergency telephone. Where's the best place to wait for help to arrive?

choices.label: Next to the phone
Well away from the carriageway
With your vehicle
On the hard shoulder

correct.text: When you're on the hard shoulder, you're at risk of being injured by motorway traffic. The safest place to wait is away from the carriageway, but near enough to see the emergency services arriving.

incorrect.text: When you're on the hard shoulder, you're at risk of being injured by motorway traffic. The safest place to wait is away from the carriageway, but near enough to see the emergency services arriving.

config.text: You're joining a motorway from a slip road. How should you deal with traffic already on the motorway?

choices.label: Carry on along the hard shoulder until you see a safe gap
Stop at the end of the slip road and look for a safe gap
Use the slip road to accelerate until you're moving much faster than the motorway traffic
Match your speed to traffic in the left-hand lane and filter into a safe gap

correct.text: You should give way to traffic already on the motorway. Where possible, traffic may move over to let you in, but don’t force your way into the traffic stream. Traffic could be travelling at high speed, so try to match your speed to filter in without affecting the traffic flow.

incorrect.text: You should give way to traffic already on the motorway. Where possible, traffic may move over to let you in, but don’t force your way into the traffic stream. Traffic could be travelling at high speed, so try to match your speed to filter in without affecting the traffic flow.

config.text: Your car gets a puncture while you're driving on the motorway. What should you do when you've stopped on the hard shoulder?

choices.label: Carefully change the wheel yourself
Use an emergency telephone and call for help
Try to wave down another vehicle for help
Only change the wheel if you have a passenger to help you

correct.text: Park as far to the left as you can and leave the vehicle by the nearside door. Don't attempt even simple repairs. Instead, walk to an emergency telephone on your side of the road and phone for help. While waiting for help to arrive, stay by your car, keeping well away from the carriageway and hard shoulder.

incorrect.text: Park as far to the left as you can and leave the vehicle by the nearside door. Don't attempt even simple repairs. Instead, walk to an emergency telephone on your side of the road and phone for help. While waiting for help to arrive, stay by your car, keeping well away from the carriageway and hard shoulder.

config.text: What's the national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway?

choices.label: 50 mph
60 mph
70 mph
80 mph

correct.text: The national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway is 70 mph. Lower speed limits may be in force; for example, at roadworks. Variable speed limits also operate in some areas when the motorway is very busy. Cars or motorcycles towing trailers are subject to a lower speed limit.

incorrect.text: The national speed limit for a car or motorcycle on a motorway is 70 mph. Lower speed limits may be in force; for example, at roadworks. Variable speed limits also operate in some areas when the motorway is very busy. Cars or motorcycles towing trailers are subject to a lower speed limit.

config.text: Your vehicle breaks down on a motorway and you need to call for help. Why might it be better to use an emergency roadside telephone rather than a mobile phone?

choices.label: It connects you to a local garage
Using a mobile phone will distract other drivers
It allows easy location by the emergency services
Mobile phones don't work on motorways

correct.text: On a motorway, it's best to use a roadside emergency telephone so that the emergency services are able to find you easily. The location of the nearest telephone is shown by an arrow on marker posts at the edge of the hard shoulder. If you use a mobile, find out the number on the nearest marker post before you call. This number will let the operator know where you are and in which direction you're travelling.

incorrect.text: On a motorway, it's best to use a roadside emergency telephone so that the emergency services are able to find you easily. The location of the nearest telephone is shown by an arrow on marker posts at the edge of the hard shoulder. If you use a mobile, find out the number on the nearest marker post before you call. This number will let the operator know where you are and in which direction you're travelling.

config.text: Why is it important to make full use of the slip road as you join a motorway?

choices.label: Because there's space available to turn round if you need to
To allow you direct access to the overtaking lanes
To allow you to fit safely into the traffic flow in the left-hand lane
Because you can continue on the hard shoulder

correct.text: Try to join the motorway without affecting the progress of the traffic in the left-hand lane and always give way to traffic already on the motorway. At busy times, you may have to slow down to merge into slow-moving traffic.

incorrect.text: Try to join the motorway without affecting the progress of the traffic in the left-hand lane and always give way to traffic already on the motorway. At busy times, you may have to slow down to merge into slow-moving traffic.

config.text: When should you use the left-hand lane of a motorway?

choices.label: When your vehicle breaks down
When you're overtaking slower traffic in the other lanes
When you're making a phone call
When the road ahead is clear

correct.text: You should drive in the left-hand lane whenever possible. Only use the other lanes for overtaking or when directed to do so by signals. Using other lanes when the left-hand lane is empty can frustrate drivers behind you.

incorrect.text: You should drive in the left-hand lane whenever possible. Only use the other lanes for overtaking or when directed to do so by signals. Using other lanes when the left-hand lane is empty can frustrate drivers behind you.

meta.xref: DES s11, HC p132, KYTS p93

config.text: What do these motorway signs mean?

choices.label: They're countdown markers to a bridge
They're distance markers to the next telephone
They're countdown markers to the next exit
They warn of a police control ahead

correct.text: The exit from a motorway is indicated by countdown markers. These are positioned 90 metres (100 yards) apart, the first being 270 metres (300 yards) from the start of the slip road. Move into the left-hand lane well before you reach the start of the slip road.

incorrect.text: The exit from a motorway is indicated by countdown markers. These are positioned 90 metres (100 yards) apart, the first being 270 metres (300 yards) from the start of the slip road. Move into the left-hand lane well before you reach the start of the slip road.

config.text: You're driving on a motorway. What does it mean if the car in front shows its hazard warning lights for a short time?

choices.label: The driver wants you to overtake
The other car is going to change lanes
Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
There's a police speed check ahead

correct.text: If the vehicle in front shows its hazard warning lights, there may be an incident, stopped traffic or queuing traffic ahead. By keeping a safe distance from the vehicle in front, you're able to look beyond it and see any hazards well ahead.

incorrect.text: If the vehicle in front shows its hazard warning lights, there may be an incident, stopped traffic or queuing traffic ahead. By keeping a safe distance from the vehicle in front, you're able to look beyond it and see any hazards well ahead.

config.text: Your vehicle breaks down on a motorway and you manage to stop on the hard shoulder. What should you do if you use your mobile phone to call for help?

choices.label: Stand at the rear of the vehicle while making the call
Phone a friend and ask them to come and collect you
Wait in the car for the emergency services to arrive
Check your location from the nearest marker posts beside the hard shoulder

correct.text: You should use an emergency telephone when you break down on the motorway; only use your mobile if this isn't possible. The emergency services need to know your exact location so they can reach you as quickly as possible. Look for a number on the nearest marker post beside the hard shoulder. Give this number when you call the emergency services.

incorrect.text: You should use an emergency telephone when you break down on the motorway; only use your mobile if this isn't possible. The emergency services need to know your exact location so they can reach you as quickly as possible. Look for a number on the nearest marker post beside the hard shoulder. Give this number when you call the emergency services.

config.text: What restrictions apply to people who have a provisional driving licence?

choices.label: They can't drive over 30 mph
They can't drive at night
They can't drive unaccompanied
They can't drive with more than one passenger

correct.text: You won't be able to drive unaccompanied until you've passed your practical driving test. If you haven't driven on the motorway while you were learning, ask your instructor to take you for a lesson on the motorway when you've passed your test. Alternatively, you could take part in the Pass Plus scheme. This has been created for new drivers and includes motorway driving. Ask your instructor for details.

incorrect.text: You won't be able to drive unaccompanied until you've passed your practical driving test. If you haven't driven on the motorway while you were learning, ask your instructor to take you for a lesson on the motorway when you've passed your test. Alternatively, you could take part in the Pass Plus scheme. This has been created for new drivers and includes motorway driving. Ask your instructor for details.

config.text: What colour are the reflective studs between the hard shoulder and the left-hand lane of a motorway?

choices.label: Green
Red
White
Amber

correct.text: Red studs are placed between the edge of the carriageway and the hard shoulder. Where slip roads leave or join the motorway, the studs are green.

incorrect.text: Red studs are placed between the edge of the carriageway and the hard shoulder. Where slip roads leave or join the motorway, the studs are green.

config.text: You're driving on a motorway and have to slow down suddenly due to a hazard ahead. How can you warn drivers behind of the hazard?

choices.label: Switch on your hazard warning lights
Switch on your headlights
Sound your horn
Flash your headlights

correct.text: Using your hazard warning lights, as well as your brake lights, will give the traffic behind an extra warning of the problem ahead. Only use them for long enough for your warning to be seen.

incorrect.text: Using your hazard warning lights, as well as your brake lights, will give the traffic behind an extra warning of the problem ahead. Only use them for long enough for your warning to be seen.

config.text: On a three-lane motorway, which lane should you use if there's no traffic ahead?

choices.label: Left
Right
Centre
Either the right or centre

correct.text: On a three-lane motorway, you should travel in the left-hand lane unless you’re overtaking. This applies regardless of the speed at which you’re travelling.

incorrect.text: On a three-lane motorway, you should travel in the left-hand lane unless you’re overtaking. This applies regardless of the speed at which you’re travelling.

config.text: Where are amber reflective studs found on a motorway?

choices.label: Between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
Between the acceleration lane and the carriageway
Between the central reservation and the carriageway
Between each pair of lanes

correct.text: On motorways, reflective studs of various colours are fixed in the road between the lanes. These help you to identify which lane you're in when it's dark or in poor visibility. Amber-coloured studs are found on the right-hand edge of the main carriageway, next to the central reservation.

incorrect.text: On motorways, reflective studs of various colours are fixed in the road between the lanes. These help you to identify which lane you're in when it's dark or in poor visibility. Amber-coloured studs are found on the right-hand edge of the main carriageway, next to the central reservation.

config.text: When would you use the right-hand lane on a three-lane motorway?

choices.label: When you're turning right
When you're overtaking
When you're travelling above the speed limit
When you're trying to save fuel

correct.text: The right-hand lane of the motorway is for overtaking. Sometimes you may be directed into a right-hand lane as a result of roadworks or a traffic incident. This will be indicated by signs or officers directing the traffic.

incorrect.text: The right-hand lane of the motorway is for overtaking. Sometimes you may be directed into a right-hand lane as a result of roadworks or a traffic incident. This will be indicated by signs or officers directing the traffic.

config.text: You're in the right-hand lane of a three-lane motorway. What do these overhead signs mean?

choices.label: Move to the left and reduce your speed to 50 mph
There are roadworks 50 metres (55 yards) ahead
Use the hard shoulder until you've passed the hazard
Leave the motorway at the next exit

correct.text: You must obey these signs even if there appear to be no problems ahead. There could be queuing traffic or another hazard that you can't see yet.

incorrect.text: You must obey these signs even if there appear to be no problems ahead. There could be queuing traffic or another hazard that you can't see yet.

config.text: What should you do when going through a contraflow system on a motorway?

choices.label: Use dipped headlights
Keep a good distance from the vehicle ahead
Switch lanes to keep the traffic flowing
Stay close to the vehicle ahead to reduce queues

correct.text:
At roadworks, and especially where a contraflow system is operating, a speed restriction is likely to be in place. Keep to the lower speed limit and don’t
  • switch lanes
  • get too close to the vehicle in front of you.
Be aware that there will be no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic.

incorrect.text:
At roadworks, and especially where a contraflow system is operating, a speed restriction is likely to be in place. Keep to the lower speed limit and don’t
  • switch lanes
  • get too close to the vehicle in front of you.
Be aware that there will be no permanent barrier between you and the oncoming traffic.

config.text: What colour are the reflective studs between a motorway and a slip road?

choices.label: Amber
White
Green
Red

correct.text: The studs between the carriageway and the hard shoulder are normally red. These change to green where there's a slip road, helping you to identify slip roads when visibility is poor or when it's dark.

incorrect.text: The studs between the carriageway and the hard shoulder are normally red. These change to green where there's a slip road, helping you to identify slip roads when visibility is poor or when it's dark.

config.text: You're on a three-lane motorway. Which lane are you in if there are red reflective studs on your left and white ones to your right?

choices.label: In the right-hand lane
In the middle lane
On the hard shoulder
In the left-hand lane

correct.text:
The colours of the reflective studs on the motorway and their locations are
  • red – between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
  • white – between lanes
  • amber – between the carriageway and the central reservation
  • green – along slip-road exits and entrances
  • bright green/yellow – at roadworks and contraflow systems.

incorrect.text:
The colours of the reflective studs on the motorway and their locations are
  • red – between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
  • white – between lanes
  • amber – between the carriageway and the central reservation
  • green – along slip-road exits and entrances
  • bright green/yellow – at roadworks and contraflow systems.

config.text: When may you stop on a motorway?

choices.label: If you have to read a map
When you're tired and need a rest
If your mobile phone rings
In an emergency or breakdown

correct.text: You shouldn't normally stop on a motorway, but there may be occasions when you need to do so. If your vehicle breaks down or there's an emergency, stop on the hard shoulder and use the emergency telephones to call for assistance.

incorrect.text: You shouldn't normally stop on a motorway, but there may be occasions when you need to do so. If your vehicle breaks down or there's an emergency, stop on the hard shoulder and use the emergency telephones to call for assistance.

config.text: Where should you stop to rest if you feel tired while you're travelling along a motorway?

choices.label: On the hard shoulder
At the nearest service area
On a slip road
On the central reservation

correct.text: If you feel tired, stop at the nearest service area. If that's too far away, leave the motorway at the next exit and find a safe place to stop. You mustn't stop on the carriageway or hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency, when in a traffic queue, or when signalled to do so by a police officer, a traffic officer or traffic signals. Plan your journey so that you have regular rest stops.

incorrect.text: If you feel tired, stop at the nearest service area. If that's too far away, leave the motorway at the next exit and find a safe place to stop. You mustn't stop on the carriageway or hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency, when in a traffic queue, or when signalled to do so by a police officer, a traffic officer or traffic signals. Plan your journey so that you have regular rest stops.

config.text: How should you position yourself when you use the emergency telephone on a motorway?

choices.label: Stay close to the carriageway
Face the oncoming traffic
Keep your back to the traffic
Stand on the hard shoulder

correct.text: Traffic is passing you at speed. If the draught from a large lorry catches you by surprise, it could blow you off balance and even onto the carriageway. By facing the oncoming traffic, you can see approaching lorries and so be prepared for their draught. You'll also be in a position to see any other hazards approaching.

incorrect.text: Traffic is passing you at speed. If the draught from a large lorry catches you by surprise, it could blow you off balance and even onto the carriageway. By facing the oncoming traffic, you can see approaching lorries and so be prepared for their draught. You'll also be in a position to see any other hazards approaching.

config.text: You're driving on the motorway. Which lane should you get into well before you reach your exit?

choices.label: The middle lane
The left-hand lane
The hard shoulder
The right-hand lane

correct.text: You’ll see the first advance direction sign one mile from a motorway exit. If you’re travelling at 60 mph in the right-hand lane, you’ll only have about 50 seconds before you reach the countdown markers. There'll be another sign at the half-mile point. Don’t cut across lanes of traffic at the last moment – move to the left-hand lane in good time.

incorrect.text: You’ll see the first advance direction sign one mile from a motorway exit. If you’re travelling at 60 mph in the right-hand lane, you’ll only have about 50 seconds before you reach the countdown markers. There'll be another sign at the half-mile point. Don’t cut across lanes of traffic at the last moment – move to the left-hand lane in good time.

config.text: When are you allowed to stop on a motorway?

choices.label: When you need to walk and get fresh air
When you wish to pick up hitchhikers
When you're signalled to do so by traffic signals
When you need to use a mobile telephone

correct.text: You must stop if overhead gantry signs show a red cross above every lane on the motorway. If any of the other lanes doesn't show a red cross, you may move into that lane and continue if it's safe to do so.

incorrect.text: You must stop if overhead gantry signs show a red cross above every lane on the motorway. If any of the other lanes doesn't show a red cross, you may move into that lane and continue if it's safe to do so.

meta.xref: DES s11, HC r258, HC r269

config.text: You're on a motorway. What does it mean when a red cross is displayed above the hard shoulder?

choices.label: Pull up in this lane to answer your mobile phone
Use this lane as a running lane
This lane can be used if you need a rest
You must not travel in this lane

correct.text: At certain times, the hard shoulder will be open as a running lane. However, a red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it is not open as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies and breakdowns.

incorrect.text: At certain times, the hard shoulder will be open as a running lane. However, a red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it is not open as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies and breakdowns.

config.text: You're towing a trailer along a three-lane motorway. When may you use the right-hand lane?

choices.label: When there are lane closures
When there's slow-moving traffic
When you can maintain a high speed
When large vehicles are in the left and centre lanes

correct.text: If you're towing a caravan or trailer, you mustn't use the right-hand lane of a motorway with three or more lanes except in certain specified circumstances, such as when lanes are closed.

incorrect.text: If you're towing a caravan or trailer, you mustn't use the right-hand lane of a motorway with three or more lanes except in certain specified circumstances, such as when lanes are closed.

config.text: What helps to reduce traffic bunching on a motorway?

choices.label: Variable speed limits
Contraflow systems
National speed limits
Lane closures

correct.text: Congestion can be reduced by keeping traffic at a constant speed. At busy times, maximum speed limits are displayed on overhead gantries. These can be varied quickly, depending on the amount of traffic. By keeping to a constant speed on busy sections of motorway, overall journey times are normally improved.

incorrect.text: Congestion can be reduced by keeping traffic at a constant speed. At busy times, maximum speed limits are displayed on overhead gantries. These can be varied quickly, depending on the amount of traffic. By keeping to a constant speed on busy sections of motorway, overall journey times are normally improved.

meta.xref: DES s11, HC r258, HC p122, KYTS p104

config.text: You're on a motorway. What must you do if there's a red cross showing above every lane?

choices.label: Pull onto the hard shoulder
Slow down and watch for further signals
Leave at the next exit
Stop and wait

correct.text: A red cross signal above all lanes means you must stop and wait. Don't change lanes and don't try to continue any further along the motorway.

incorrect.text: A red cross signal above all lanes means you must stop and wait. Don't change lanes and don't try to continue any further along the motorway.

config.text: You're travelling along a motorway. Where would you find a crawler or climbing lane?

choices.label: On a steep gradient
Before a service area
Before a junction
Along the hard shoulder

correct.text: Large, slow-moving vehicles can hinder the progress of other traffic. On a steep gradient, an extra crawler lane may be provided for slow-moving vehicles to allow faster-moving traffic to flow more easily.

incorrect.text: Large, slow-moving vehicles can hinder the progress of other traffic. On a steep gradient, an extra crawler lane may be provided for slow-moving vehicles to allow faster-moving traffic to flow more easily.
